entry.title: Re: VK13 issue
entry.content:
Go to v/07 and check all the fields used in the first access sequence are correctly mapped and active. From technical angle, sometimes, a field like LAND1 may be mapped incorrectly to LAND1Z, which causes it to disappear from the display in VK13

Sometimes, the TR would not have imported properly into production. Check in VK+C and regenerate the condition table if needed. Check VAKEY as per this discussion

entry.title: Re: Launching My Custom SAPUI5 App in S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello @marceloromeiro 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, you cannot create a custom tile directly by simply pasting the deployed app URL and linking it to a Z-catalogue. The supported method is to utilise the Custom Catalogue Extensions and Custom Tiles functionality within the Launchpad Designer.

Deploy your RAP/UI5 app – you have already done this. It should be visible within the deployed HTML5 applications.

Create a customised business catalogue (Z-catalogue) using the Maintain Catalogue Extensions app.

Create a custom tile using the Manage Launchpad Apps app (not a direct URL). Select your deployed app from the list of available apps.

Assign the app to your custom Z-catalogue via the same app.

Finally, assign the catalogue to the relevant business role in Maintain Business Roles so that users see the tile in their Launchpad.

You need to register the deployed UI5 app as a Launchpad App and assign it through a Z-catalogue created via the in-app extensibility tools. Directly linking a URL to a catalogue is not supported in Public Cloud

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Introducing SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4
entry.content:
Exploring the SAP BTP Guidance Framework - Extensibility

I am pleased to announce the availability of the SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4. In this blog post, I would like to provide a quick overview and highlight the changes in this newest release.

For a quick introduction to the methodology, please take a look here: SAP Application Extension Methodology.

This blog post is part of the series SAP BTP Guidance Framework: A Compass for Architects, Developers, and Administrators.

The SAP BTP Guidance Framework is a practical framework tailored to anyone using the SAP Business Technology Platform. SAP BTP acts as the technological backbone for building, integrating, extending, and innovating with SAP solutions. Whether you're an enterprise architect, software developer, or administrator, SAP BTP offers significant opportunities for productivity and development.

 

What’s New for SAP Application Extension Methodology

With the SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4, we have made some changes to the Extension Technology Mapping. We now include the Clean Core Level concept directly in the Mapping, allowing you to easily follow the latest guidance. Next to each Technical Extension Building Block, you can find the corresponding Clean Core Level (A-D).

SAP Application Extension Methodology - Extension Technology Mapping with Clean Core Levels

Please be aware that the single source of truth for the Clean Core Levels is the official SAP Note 3578329. 

If you are still using an older version of the Technology Mapping, I highly recommend checking out our new version and to learn about the latest innovations and technologies on SAP S/4HANA and SAP Business Technology Platform.

 

Clean Core Level Concept in a Nutshell

Clean Core Levels Overview

TL;DR

  • Always develop your extension with the highest clean core level.
  • Leverage released APIs and best practice classic APIs of Level A and B to be clean core compliant.
  • Avoid not recommended SAP objects of Level D as they are not clean core compliant.

Level A

Level A is considered clean core and your strategic direction. You develop extension with SAP Build either on-stack on SAP S/4HANA and/or Side-by-Side on SAP BTP. Usually, you use a combination of both. You will use ABAP Cloud, CAP and our low-code/no-code tools in SAP Build. You can find the released APIs and extensions points on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Level B

Level B is considered clean core. You use upgrade stable classic APIs, which you can find in the cloudification repository viewer with filter state = classic API.

Level C

Level C is considered conditionally clean. Use the internal SAP objects only if needed. There is no guarantee on long-term stability. Apply the changelog for SAP objects to mitigate upgrade risks.

Level D

Level D is considered NOT clean core. Those objects are unfit for customer use. You can find them in the cloudification repository viewer with filter state = noAPI.

 

Next Steps:

Learn more about the SAP Application Extension Methodology on the SAP Help Portal.

Learn more about the SAP BTP Guidance Framework on the SAP Discovery Center and look out for the continuation of the blog post series. The next one will be about Data&Analytics.

Learn more about Clean Core by reading our detailed whitepaper, or tune into our latest Unlocking SAP BTP podcast episode focusing on clean core.

Feel free to like, comment and ask your questions!

Talk to you soon,
Marco

Product Manager SAP Business Technology Platform

Join me online: https://www.linkedin.com/in/marcomatha/

entry.title: Re: SAC Scripting
entry.content:
@shiva1233 

/ Assuming your table is named "Table_1" and your dropdown is "Dropdown_1"
// And the dimension you are filtering is "YourDimension"
To set the dropdown with filter values from table, the dropdown should have those values as possible selection. I will assume that you already have it.

Adjust accordingly

// Reading the Table filters
var oFilter = Table_1.getDataSource().getDimensionFilters("yourDimension");
console.log(["getFilter ",oFilter]);
var strFilter = [""];


if (oFilter[0].type === FilterValueType.Single){
	var sfv = cast(Type.SingleFilterValue,oFilter[0]);
	strFilter = [sfv.value];
}
else{
	var mfv = cast(Type.MultipleFilterValue,oFilter[0]);
	for (var i=0, len=mfv.values.length; i< len; i++){
		strFilter.push(mfv.values[i]);
	}
	
}


Dropdown_1.setSelectedKey(strFilter)

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: Schedule OverView (Capacity Planning) Reddening, even...
entry.content:
Hello @SI_y_Ito 

The red highlighting in the Gantt/resource view not only shows an overlap of bars but also usually indicates a capacity conflict, for instance, when the assigned work exceeds the resource’s available hours according to its work calendar, or when there is an overlap at a more detailed level, an hourly view that isn’t visible in the weekly zoom.

I recommend checking the resource utilisation view, verifying the work calendar, and zooming in on a daily/hourly level to see where the overload occurs. Other assignments from outside your current filter can also cause the same effect.

Useful: SAP Help Portal – Resource Scheduling in S/4HANA Cloud

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Error CRToWords.DLL” and “Load report failed” during PDF Generation in SAP B1 HANA Add-On
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

We are currently using SAP Business One 10.0 (HANA) and have developed a custom add-on to send emails to customers with the corresponding Invoice PDF attached.

As part of the process, we are converting a Crystal Report (.rpt) file to PDF using a PDF generator executable, and then sending the output via email. This works as expected on our Windows Server and several local machines.

However, on multiple user systems, we are encountering the following error during PDF conversion:

ExportToPdf Cannot find "CRToWords.DLL".
Error in File C:\Users\Intern\AppData\Local\Temp\AR {E93D4A7D-C4DF-4770-BBD8-A77207E508F2}.rpt:
Error in formula <Amt in Wds>.
Cannot find "CRToWords_??.DLL".

Additional Context:

  • The report includes a formula to convert the invoice amount into words, which uses a UFL (User Function Library).

  • If we suppress this formula, the PDF conversion works. But this logic is business-critical and cannot be removed.

  • The issue occurs only on specific client machines, not all systems.

    Even after removing the formula (for testing), we now see this error on the same machines:

    01/09/2025 5:19:12 PM : connstring
    01/09/2025 5:19:12 PM : Starting
    01/09/2025 5:19:12 PM : strfn Y:\invoices\AMT_INV_278315.pdf
    01/09/2025 5:19:12 PM : RPTPath 'Y:\RPT\AR.rpt'
    01/09/2025 5:19:12 PM : ExportToPdf: Load report failed.

entry.title: Strengthening Financial Master Data with CDQ's Bank Account API: Real-Time Fraud Detection in MDG
entry.content:
Executive Summary 

Organizations face an increasing risk of fraud in vendor payments and financial master data. This blog introduces a lightweight SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) enhancement that integrates CDQ's Bank Account API to validate bank trustworthiness and detect fraud — in real-time — directly within the Change Request process. 

 

Introduction

Data quality in financial master data plays a crucial role in maintaining integrity and trust across the enterprise. Especially with increasing cases of fraud targeting bank account information, it has become vital to validate this data against trusted external sources. This blog post demonstrates how to integrate CDQ's Bank Account Data API into SAP MDG to detect and warn about known fraud cases in real time during the Change Request process. 

 

Background

Corporate Data Quality (CDQ) is a cloud-based platform that enables organizations to access verified, trusted data by connecting to official and commercial registers worldwide. While it is widely used for sourcing company information such as legal names, tax numbers, and registration data, CDQ also offers APIs for verifying bank accounts, which play a growing role in fraud prevention and financial data governance.

In my previous blog post, I demonstrated how to create a custom DPI integration solution in SAP for Business Partner creation using a Custom List UIBB and REST API calls to CDQ. This blog builds on that architectural pattern, extending it to the bank account domain using CDQ’s Bank Account Data API to validate and assess trust levels of banks directly within the Change Request process.

 

Feasible Option - Abstract

SAP MDG Classic Mode does not natively support dynamic bank account validation using external risk intelligence. However, this limitation can be overcome by integrating CDQ’s Bank Account Data API into the Change Request (CR) process via a custom-built API integration. This enables the following capabilities:

  • Fraud Detection: Detect if a bank is blacklisted or associated with a known fraud case.
  • Reputation Scoring: Retrieve and display the bank accounts' trust score for transparency and risk assessment.
  • Real-Time Messaging: Show contextual messages — either warnings (blacklisted) or information (whitelisted) — directly in the UI during CR processing.

For example:
If a blacklisted bank is entered: ⚠️ Bank & is in blacklist, one of fraud case ID: &

Figure 1 – Warning message after a bank in the blacklist is entered

 If a whitelisted bank is used with a known trust score: ✅ Bank & is in whitelist, trust score: &

Figure 2 – Information message after a bank in the whitelist is entered

This solution provides a feasible, low-effort, and value-driven way to bring real-time banking insights into your SAP MDG environment.

 

Some Nice-To-Have Skills

Here are some nice-to-have skills and knowledge areas for handling this topic:

ABAP programming, T-Code: SM59, SM30, STRUST, USMD_RULE_SERVICE BadI Definition, REST API, RFC, MDG

 

Solution in a Nutshell

This solution enhances SAP MDG's Change Request process by verifying bank account data in real time via CDQ’s Bank Account Data API. The goal is to detect potential fraud or confirm the trustworthiness of a bank at the moment it is entered in the Change Request.

Here's how it works:

  1. The user adds a bank account in a CR (only IBAN or bank account number & bank code/number & bank country code).
  2. Upon entry, background logic triggers a call to CDQ’s Bank Account Data API (POST /v2/bankaccounts/confirm).
  3. The response returns whether the bank:
    • ✅Is in the whitelist, along with a trust score (e.g., trustScore: 27).
    • ⚠️Has one or more fraud cases, with related metadata like fraudCaseId.
  4. SAP MDG then displays a contextual message in the UI based on the result:
    • If the bank is whitelisted: ✅ Bank 0002 is in whitelist, trust score: 27
    • If the bank is flagged for fraud: ⚠️ Bank 0001 is in blacklist, one of fraud case ID: UUIK5gGCQD

This provides immediate, actionable feedback to master data stewards before the data is activated, reducing the risk of onboarding risky bank accounts.

 

Implementation Steps

For our solution, we pursued the following steps:

  • Create an API Key Instance from CDQ with a Client ID and Client Secret. For more information, please visit this site.
  • Import TLS root certificate for https://api.cdq.com. For more information, check out this blog.
  • Maintain the required RFC Destinations to set up technical communication.
  • Determine the logical port as the DPI’s general RFC Destination. Configure the V_MDQDPI_RFCDEST view in SM30.
  • Create these classes to implement the logic;
    1. API Caller Class (ZCL_CDQ_API_CALLER) -> Handling API requests, communicating with CDQ
    2. Main Integration Class (ZCL_CDQ_BP_INTEGRATION) -> Prepare the request data and trigger the POST method
    3. Validation Class (ZCL_BP_CDQ_VALIDATION) -> Display the outcome of the API in Change Request
    4. Utilities Class (ZCL_BP_CDQ_UTILITIES) -> Collect useful methods that are used several times

Create New API Key;

Figure 3 – Generating API Key from CDQ Portal for Secure Integration

To establish secure HTTPS communication with CDQ, the certificate for api.cdq.com must be imported via transaction STRUST. This is depicted in Figure 4, where the certificate is added under the SSL Client (Standard);

Figure 4 – Certification for CDQ API

Set up External Server HTTP Connections;

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Figure 5 – RFC Connections for CDQ

The created RFC Destination Z_DPI_CDQ is assigned as the logical port for DPI’s general operation. You can see this configuration in Figure 6, which shows the entry in the V_MDQDPI_RFCDEST view;

 

 

 

 


Figure 6 – Data entry for V_MDQDPI_RFCDEST to determine logical port for general DPI operations

Remark: The following methods will be the main part of the framework, they do not include the whole picture.

The method responsible for communicating with CDQ (ZCL_CDQ_API_CALLER->CALL_API);

  METHOD call_api.

    TRY.
        DATA(rfc_destination) = get_rfc_destination( if_mdqdpi_rfc_dest_constants=>provider-cdq-operation-general-name ).

        IF rest_client IS NOT BOUND.
          DATA(http_client) = get_http_client( rfc_destination ).

          cl_http_utility=>set_request_uri( request = http_client->request
                                            uri     = api_path ).

          rest_client = NEW cl_rest_http_client( http_client ).
        ENDIF.

      CATCH cx_mdqdpi_functional_error.
        rfc_destination = get_rfc_destination( if_mdqdpi_rfc_dest_constants=>provider-cdq-operation-lookup-name ).
        IF rest_client IS NOT BOUND.
          http_client = get_http_client( rfc_destination ).
          rest_client = NEW cl_rest_http_client( http_client ).
        ENDIF.
        IF rest_client IS INITIAL.
          RAISE EXCEPTION NEW cx_mdqdpi_functional_error( textid = cx_mdqdpi_functional_error=>data_provider_setup_error ).
        ENDIF.
    ENDTRY.

    DATA(request) = build_request( payload = payload
                                   mapping = mapping ).
    rest_client->post( request ).
    result = rest_client->get_response_entity( )->get_string_data( ).
    analyze_response(
      EXPORTING
        string_response  = result
        rest_client      = rest_client                 " REST Client
      IMPORTING
        http_status_code = http_status_code
    ).

    rest_client->close( ).
    CLEAR rest_client.

  ENDMETHOD.

 The method responsible for preparing the API response for validation BAdI (ZCL_CDQ_BP_INTEGRATION->BANK_RELIABILITY);

  METHOD bank_reliability.

    DATA:
      ls_abap_format  TYPE zif_cdq_bp_integration=>gty_bank_reliability_response,
      ls_t100_message TYPE scx_t100key.

    CLEAR:
      ev_status,
      es_cdq_bank_response,
      et_t100_message.

    DATA(name_mappings) = VALUE /ui2/cl_json=>name_mappings( ( abap = 'bank_code'      json = 'nationalBankIdentifier' )
                                                             ( abap = 'iban'           json = 'internationalBankAccountIdentifier' )
                                                             ( abap = 'account_number' json = 'nationalBankAccountIdentifier' )
                                                             ( abap = 'bic'            json = 'internationalBankIdentifier' ) ).

    DATA(api_caller) = zcl_cdq_api_caller=>get_instance( ).

    TRY.
        api_caller->call_api(
          EXPORTING
            api_path         = '/sap-odm/v3/bankaccount-data/rest/v2/bankaccounts/confirm'
            payload          = is_cdq_bank_request
            mapping          = name_mappings                 " ABAP<->JSON Name Mapping Table
          IMPORTING
            result           = DATA(http_response)
            http_status_code = ev_status
        ).

      CATCH cx_mdqdpi_functional_error INTO DATA(lx_error).

*     General error message info
        CLEAR ls_t100_message.
        ls_t100_message = lx_error->if_t100_message~t100key.
        go_bp_cdq_utilities->prepare_t100_message(
          EXPORTING
            ix_error        = lx_error                 " Functional Errors
          CHANGING
            cs_t100_message = ls_t100_message                 " T100 key with mapping of parameters to attribute names
        ).
        IF ls_t100_message IS NOT INITIAL.
          APPEND ls_t100_message TO et_t100_message.
        ENDIF.

*     Detailed error message info if exists
        IF lx_error->previous IS NOT INITIAL.
          CLEAR ls_t100_message.
          DATA(lx_previos_error) = CAST cx_mdqdpi_functional_error( lx_error->previous ).
          ls_t100_message = lx_previos_error->if_t100_message~t100key.
          go_bp_cdq_utilities->prepare_t100_message(
            EXPORTING
              ix_error        = lx_previos_error                 " Functional Errors
            CHANGING
              cs_t100_message = ls_t100_message                 " T100 key with mapping of parameters to attribute names
          ).
          IF ls_t100_message IS NOT INITIAL.
            APPEND ls_t100_message TO et_t100_message.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.
        EXIT.
    ENDTRY.

    convert_to_abap_format(
      EXPORTING
        iv_data_in_json_format       = http_response
        iv_api_type                  = 'BANK_REL'                 " LOOK_UP / BANK_REL / EMAIL
      IMPORTING
        es_cdq_bank_response = es_cdq_bank_response                 " Bank Reliability Response Type
    ).

*  If the bank account has no trust score or fraud case, the bank account is unknown for CDQ
    IF      es_cdq_bank_response-trust_score            IS INITIAL
        AND es_cdq_bank_response-associated_fraud_cases IS INITIAL.
      es_cdq_bank_response-is_bank_unkown  = abap_true.
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.

 

Conclusion

As organizations increasingly rely on external banking data for payments, compliance, and onboarding, trusted bank account validation becomes a critical part of financial master data governance. This integration with CDQ’s Bank Account Data API provides SAP MDG users with real-time insights into the trust level and potential fraud risk of a bank—before the data is activated.

By embedding this verification into the Change Request process:

  • Stewards are empowered to act immediately on risks.
  • Fraud-prone banks can be flagged and avoided.
  • Clean, verified bank accounts improve downstream processes like payments and compliance reporting.

This approach not only enhances data quality and integrity but also supports key organizational goals: minimizing risk, preventing fraud, and building a solid foundation for digital finance processes.

Whether in finance, procurement, or vendor onboarding, this solution helps ensure that the bank accounts you rely on are exactly what they claim to be: trusted.

entry.title: Re: In a script, how do I check if an LDM Entity is a subtype?
entry.content:
Hi George,

I just checked my PD 16.7 SP07 PL02 documentation. It states that EntityAttribute (LDM) has InheritedFrom and InheritanceSource properties (not collections!) and both contain the EntityAttribute from the parent entity (meaning they are inherited).
An Entity has SuperEntities and InheritsFrom collections. The first contains all parent entities, and the second contains collections of InheritanceLinks.

So, by checking each attribute for:

  • not having an InheritedFrom property defined (i.e., Nothing)
    AND

  • not being part of the Primary Key (PrimaryIdentifier property)

you should get your list of logical attributes to export. This seems achievable to me, but maybe I am missing something from your description. See my example on the screenshot below.

Here is my code:

For each e in activemodel.entities
  output "============"  
  output e.name
  output "-------------"
  If not (e.ParentEntity is Nothing) then
    output "Parent entity: " + e.PArentEntity
  End if
  For each se in e.SuperEntities          ' collection
    output "SuperEntities: " + se.Name + " (" + se.ObjectType + ")"
  Next
  For each ifr in e.InheritsFrom
    'output "InheritsFrom: " + ifr.Name + " (" + ifr.OBjectType + ")"
  Next
  
  output "-------------"
  For each a in e.Attributes
    output a.Name & " - " & a.PrimaryIdentifier
    If not (a.InheritedFrom is Nothing) then        ' just property
      output "inherited From: " + a.InheritedFrom + " (" + a.InheritedFrom.ObjectType + ")"
    End if
    If not (a.InheritanceSource is Nothing) then    ' just property
      output "inheritanceSource: " + a.InheritanceSource  + " (" + a.InheritanceSource.ObjectType + ")"
    End if
  Next
Next

 

Let me know,
Ondrej

P.S. "Pravda" stands for True and "Nepravda" for False in my Output window.

entry.title: How to Implement Request-Reply over HTTP → MQ → HTTP using SAP CI
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am working on a scenario where I need to implement a request-reply pattern in SAP Cloud Integration (SAP CI), and I would appreciate your guidance.

Scenario:

  • Source System: Has HTTP capability (sends request over HTTP to SAP CI).
  • Target System: Exposes only IBM MQ queues (request Q and reply Q).
  • Middleware: SAP Cloud Integration.
  • Current Adapter Usage: For other existing flows, we are using the AMQP adapter in SAP CI to read/write data asynchronously to IBM MQ.

Requirement:

  1. Source system sends a request payload over HTTP to SAP CI.
  2. SAP CI needs to forward this request to the target system’s request queue in IBM MQ.
    – While sending, we should add a ReplyToQ in the message header.
  3. Target system processes the request and sends a response to the reply queue with the CorrelationId.
  4. SAP CI should pick the message from the reply queue, correlate it with the original request, and then send the response back to the source system as the HTTP reply.

This was quite straightforward to implement in IBM IIB. But in SAP CI, I am struggling on how do we achieve the synchronous request-reply behavior across HTTP → AMQP → HTTP?

I am quite new to SAP CI, so any step-by-step guidance, examples, or references would be extremely helpful.

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: Re: Copy Operator
entry.content:
Hello @Thangadurai 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Planning), the behaviour you mention is normal. The Copy Operator does not generate new planning objects at the target level; it merely copies data into existing ones.

In your case:

  • Source level: MTHPRDID (root: PRDID)
  • Target level: MTHPRDIDLOC (root: PRDID & LOCID)

If the PRDID and LOCID combinations are not yet available in the target planning level, the copy will run successfully, but no data will be written.

 How to resolve in Public Cloud:

  1. Ensure the master data (product-location combinations) exists and is active.
  2. Use the Create Planning Objects operator for the target level (MTHPRDIDLOC).
  3. After the objects exist, re-run the Copy Operator – data will then populate the target key figure.

SAP Help Portal – Planning Operators in S/4HANA Cloud

SAP Help Portal – Create Planning Objects

The copy operator does not create missing planning objects; they must be created beforehand for data to be transferred to the target key figure.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Custom Navigation on Table card in OVP floorplan
entry.content:
can you try to replace the your  webapp/ext/custom.js with this and check if it works, just typed something up and not tested it, but it may helps you:

sap.ui.define([], function () {
  "use strict";

  return {
    getRetNavParams: function (context, selectionVariant, cardProps) {
      // Extract TechnicalId
      const tech = context.getProperty("TechnicalId");
      return tech ? { TechnicalId: tech } : {};
    },

    //  override the target entirely
    doCustomNavigation: function (cardId, context, stdNavEntry) {
      if (cardId === "ReturnsTable" && context) {
        const tech = context.getProperty("TechnicalId");
        return {
          type: "com.sap.vocabularies.UI.v1.DataFieldForIntentBasedNavigation",
          semanticObject: "Return",
          action: "display"
        };
        // or may use DataFieldWithUrl here
      }
      // return nothing should use the standard navigation
    }
  };
});

entry.title: Environment, Health and Safety in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP's ready-to-run public cloud ERP software solution.   

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data, and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the cloud ERP ecosystem–customers, partners, and SAP experts.  

 

In this blog post I’d like to outline the innovations for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 in the area of Environment, Health and Safety. These are the topics that are covered:

  • Management and applicability for compliance obligation registers (4C8)
  • Conversational Incident (Safety Observations) with Joule (cloud) (4YX)
  • Key performance indicators and safety insights for workplace safety (cloud) (4YX)

 

In case you do not need all the information below and briefly want to get an overview of the release highlights, please watch this video with the top three key innovations:

 

 

Video#1: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 for Environment, Health and Safety

 

Management and applicability for compliance obligation registers

Business Background


We delve into the evolution of compliance management with our newly introduced "Compliance Obligation Registers." This capability is designed to streamline the tracking and fulfillment of regulatory and internal compliance obligations, all within a centralized app. With the "Manage Compliance Register," EHS managers can seamlessly navigate through obligations tied to specific locations and subjects like air, waste, and water. The app’s structured interface illuminates each obligation’s applicability and fulfillment status through intuitive colour coding, allowing managers to quickly assess compliance health and pinpoint areas requiring attention.

Key Feature

The integration of an enhanced operational compliance overview app provides stakeholders with analytical dashboards that track compliance performance. This empowers teams to maintain operational continuity by quickly identifying compliance lapses and facilitating swift corrective actions. By optimizing change logs to ensure audit trails and data traceability, businesses can now confidently navigate the complexities of compliance, bolstering both operational transparency and efficiency. Ultimately, this innovation not only promises seamless compliance management but also equips organizations with the insights needed to strategically plan and prioritize their compliance strategies.

 

 

Video#2: Management and applicability for compliance obligation registers

 

Conversational Incident (Safety Observations) with Joule (cloud)

Business Background

Moving on to employee safety reporting, our new AI-assisted "Safety Observation Recording Tool" underscores our commitment to enhancing workplace safety through technology. This tool empowers employees to report safety observations naturally and conversationally, minimizing the friction traditionally associated with incident reporting. By utilizing AI to parse and structure conversational inputs into formal reports, this tool accelerates incident logging, ensuring no detail is overlooked and every safety concern is addressed promptly.

Key Feature

The value proposition of this innovation lies in its ability to promote a proactive safety culture. By streamlining the reporting process, employees are encouraged to participate actively in safety programs, effectively turning every member of the workforce into a potential safety advocate. Moreover, the automatically structured data allows companies to rapidly identify and prioritize safety concerns, prompting timely interventions that mitigate risks before they escalate. This seamless interplay between technology and human initiative enhances safety standards and fosters a collaborative approach to workplace safety across all organizational levels.

 

 

Video#3: Conversational Incident (Safety Observations) with Joule (cloud)

 

Key performance indicators and safety insights for workplace safety (cloud)

Business Background

Finally, our "Workplace Safety Insights" application introduces a new paradigm in safety performance management. By leveraging real-time data, this tool provides managers with dynamic insight cards that enable continuous monitoring of safety metrics. From regulatory compliance KPIs to operational safety trends, these cards offer a multifaceted view that helps managers identify potential risk areas and address them through data-driven decisions.


Key Feature


This innovation is key to establishing a sustainable safety environment by identifying potential issues before they become critical. The real-time analysis allows safety managers to implement preventive actions and corrective strategies, maintaining a high standard of safety operations. Through these strategic insights, companies can not only ensure compliance but also promote a culture of safety vigilance that permeates the entire organization.

 

 

Video#4: Key performance indicators and safety insights for workplace safety (cloud)

Thanks for taking the time to read this blog.

Don’t hesitate to leave a comment and check out our community page to ask your questions and engage with the experts. Follow the PSCC_Enablement tag to stay up to date with our latest blog posts. 

 

More Information

If you want to learn more in-depth, just a heads-up that from September 30th to October 2nd, the virtual EHS & Product Compliance Infodays are taking place. You can register here to see the agenda and join the event.

From July 21-25, we hosted a series of 21 compelling live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. entry.title: Re: CPI - iFLOW - OData Receiver POST Call - Request Payload Parsing Failed
Re: 無法選到報工項目
entry.content:
答案基于机器翻译:

你好@MartinJou 

在SAP S/4HANA EPPM中，仅在“管理项目需求”应用中创建资源需求，并不会自动使该需求在“管理我的工时表”应用中可用以进行时间记录。要启用工时表登记功能，需检查以下设置和先决条件：

需检查的关键事项

  1.     需求必须转换为可执行的工作包/活动

o             创建需求后，必须将其分配至项目结构元素（WBS/活动/工作包）。

o    工时表仅针对可执行工作对象进行记录，不支持独立需求。

  1.     角色与资源的映射关系

o             确保需求中的角色/技能已分配至项目活动，并关联至特定员工（具有员工角色的业务伙伴）。

o    若未分配员工，该活动将不会出现在其工时表中。

  1.     成本费率仅用于定价

o    您提及设置“管理成本费率服务”，这适用于费率计算。

o             但该功能不控制工时录入。关键在于需求是否已映射至带员工分配的工作包/活动。

  1.     工时表可见性

o    在“管理我的工时表”中，员工仅能查看明确分配给他们的活动或工作包。

o    若无分配关系，该选项将不会出现在工时表中。

以下是建议的解决步骤：

  1.     返回“管理项目需求”界面，确认该需求已分配至项目活动/工作包。
  2.     在项目结构中检查：该活动是否已分配给员工/角色，且该员工作为活跃业务伙伴持有员工角色。
  3.     确认该活动已标记为“启用时间记录”状态。
  4.     随后使用该员工账户登录“管理我的工时表”，确认该活动可供登记。

希望此方案能达成预期效果。如有其他疑问，欢迎随时垂询。

此致

敬礼

Chris

entry.title: How to improve the performance of prepared statements over stored procedures on SAP ASE 16?
entry.content:
I am using SAP (Sybase) Adaptive Server Enterprise (ASE) 16. I am using jConnect 4 in version 7.07. The application I'm working on serves thousands of users concurrently. It is a Java monolith hosted on ~ 5 different VMs. So multiple Java process on multiple VMs with different connections are executing mainly procedures and some statements.

I have a stored procedure that contains a rather simple query, equivalent to this one (I have changed the column names for this example):

select o.item_id, o.option_uuid, c.product_description, o.option_size
from options_rm o
left join options_products_rm c on c.id = o.product_id
where o.item_id = @item_id

At peak load, there are about 1200 executions in a given 30 seconds window of this procedure. On average, the procedure takes about 1.31 ms to complete.

I have now replaced the stored procedure with a prepared statement using the exact same SQL query. There are no comments inside the SQL query.

The prepared statement takes about 1.8 ms to complete. This is about 37 % longer than the stored procedure. The same phenomenon happens when applied to other prepared statements compared to stored procedures.

Here is a quick rundown of the Sybase ASE database setup:

  • Since I am using jConnect 4, DYNAMIC_PREPARE should be true by default.
  • The statement cache size is set to 2048 memory pages (2K).
  • The memory used of statement cache size is 4784 kilobytes.
  • streamlined dynamic SQL is enabled.
  • enable literal autoparam is enabled.
  • dynamic sql plan pinning is enabled.
  • enable plan sharing is enabled.
  • optimizer level is set to ase_current.

Why does the prepared statement take so much longer than the procedure, even though its execution plan etc. should already be cached? How can I improve the performance of prepared statements on SAP ASE 16?

entry.title: Product Compliance in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP's ready-to-run public cloud ERP software solution.  

 SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data, and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the cloud ERP ecosystem–customers, partners, and SAP experts.  

 

In this blog post I’d like to outline the innovations for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 in the area of Product Compliance. These are the topics that are covered:

  • Classifying dangerous goods packaged in logistics packing instructions (3FC)
  • EU safety data sheet generation for first scenarios and product groups (7DO)
  • Support of branded products in the safety data sheet process (3VR)

In case you do not need all the information below and briefly want to get an overview of the release highlights, please watch this video with the top three key innovations:

 

 

Video#1: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 for Product Compliance

 

Classifying dangerous goods packaged in logistics packing instructions

 

Business Background

This feature revolutionizes compliance management by enabling users to manage and maintain compliance for products packaged through logistics instructions from handling unit management. By seamlessly integrating with our existing classification app for packaged products, this innovation allows businesses to comply with various dangerous goods regulations more efficiently. The integration not only enhances accuracy in classification but also simplifies the overarching regulatory processes, reducing the complexity traditionally associated with managing dangerous goods.

 

Key Feature

This enhancement facilitates a systematic approach to compliance, leveraging the strengths of both classification apps to forge a cohesive, streamlined process. Companies can now ensure that compliance standards are met across the board by aligning logistic packing instructions with the regulatory demands of dangerous goods. This capability ultimately results in a more coherent compliance strategy that mitigates potential risks and fosters a safer operational environment.

 

Video#2: Classifying dangerous goods packaged in logistics packing instructions

 

EU safety data sheet generation for first scenarios and product groups

 

Business Background

Our safety data sheet (SDS) generation feature has received significant enhancement to support first scenarios and product groups, particularly tailored for European Union compliance requirements. Leveraging integrated regulatory content for GHS specification, this feature ensures that your safety data sheets are comprehensive and meet the highest standards. One of the standout aspects is its incorporation of a starter template, allowing for customization to fit the unique needs of your business while maintaining compliance integrity.

 

Key Feature

A key complement to this is the new preview functionality, which offers the ability to verify end products before distribution, adding an essential layer of quality assurance in documentation. By ensuring the accuracy and compliance of each document before it reaches stakeholders, the enhancement minimizes the risk of non-compliance and potential disruptions. This innovative solution not only supports compliance practices but enhances them, offering a smooth path to achieving regulatory standards.

 

 

Video#3: EU safety data sheet generation for first scenarios and product groups

 

Support of branded products in the safety data sheet process

 

Business Background

Our third key innovation is the support for branded products within the SDS process, which provides an entirely new dimension to product compliance management. This feature allows businesses to create and manage branded products distinctly from unpackaged or packaged ones, ensuring that they are accurately reflected in safety data sheets and other critical compliance documents. This added layer of flexibility allows organizations to represent their product portfolio authentically, while still adhering to rigorous compliance requirements.

 

Key Feature

In addition, the branded products support means that businesses can optimize their regulatory processes for product differentiation, enabling them to stand out in the market while maintaining stringent compliance. By integrating branded names and specific product branding details into compliance documentation, companies are provided with the tools to navigate complex brand management issues with ease. This feature is especially useful for businesses with extensive product lines, permitting them to handle compliance needs across diverse product offerings seamlessly.

 

Video#4: Support of branded products in the safety data sheet process



The value proposition we offer with Release 2508 is substantial. By integrating these innovations, we empower organizations to manage their product compliance with unprecedented ease and efficiency. You gain reliable compliance mechanisms that support global trade, mitigate risks, and protect your reputation. Our tools also help reduce administrative overhead and expedite the time-to-market by automating complex tasks and diminishing potential errors in compliance processes.

Thanks for taking the time to read this blog.

Don’t hesitate to leave a comment and check out our community page to ask your questions and engage with the experts. Follow the PSCC_Enablement tag to stay up to date with our latest blog posts. 

 

More Information

 

If you want to learn more in-depth, just a heads-up that from September 30th to October 2nd, the virtual EHS & Product Compliance Infodays are taking place. You can register here to see the agenda and join the event.



📽️ Watch the replays of our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Early Release Series! 

From July 21-25, we hosted a series of 21 compelling live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You will find the recording and presentation for LoB/Industry/Topic as well as 20 other topics of interest. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand–anywhere, anytime.

entry.title: Re: BEHAVIOR_STATEMENT_ILLEGAL error using EML for entity...
entry.content:
Hello @TajShaik 

You’re encountering BEHAVIOR_STATEMENT_ILLEGAL because MODIFY ENTITIES (EML) is only allowed during the interaction phase and within the finalise method of a saver, not during save/commit processing or in UPDATE TASK contexts. In your flow, after posting the material document via the public API—which triggers its own save/commit—your action continues in a state where EML is not permitted, hence the dump. SAP Help Portal/ABAP Keyword Documentation

What needs to be changed
Choose one of these supported patterns

  1. Do the EML update earlier (interaction phase).
    Update I_ServiceOrderTP.requestedServiceStartDateTime before calling the material document API, such as during the interaction phase. SAP Help Portal
  2. Split the steps into two LUWs.
    After the API finishes, trigger the service-order update in a separate behaviour session (e.g., an asynchronous follow-up or a small wrapper that runs after commit), or call the released OData API for Service Order in a new HTTP call—outside the current save. (EML across a foreign BO is not allowed during save.) SAP Help Portal
  3. Only for the same BO changes in save:
    If you must adjust your own BO during save, use MODIFY ENTITIES **IN LOCAL MODE** inside finalise but this works only for the same BO, not for I_ServiceOrderTP (a foreign/reuse BO). SAP Help Portal

Why the dump points to CL_IRES_RESERVATION...
That class shows you where you are in the runtime that processes the save/commit logic. In that status, EML modify is disallowed by design. SAP Help Portal/Save Sequence Runtime

References

  • ABAP Keyword Doc – MODIFY ENTITY/ENTITIES usage restrictions (allowed phases). SAP Help Portal ABAP Keyword Documentation
  • SAP Help – Interaction phase & save sequence (where EML is legal). SAP Help Portal/Implementing the Interaction Phase and the Save Sequence

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Custom CDS view Partner OrganizationName1 display
entry.content:
Hello @ISoma 

Following up on your question regarding the inclusion of Ship-To partner address details for example Name1, street and city into your Custom CDS View for Service Contracts, here is the recommended approach for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

  1. First is the Base Data Source. Continue using your service contract interface view as the primary source.
  2. The next thing is to join to Service Contract Partners
  • Add an association to I_ServiceContractPartner.
  • Join on ServiceContract = ServiceContract.
  • You need to expose BusinessPartner (Ship-To BP), AddressID (if maintained) and PartnerFunction (to filter Ship-To, typically function code = WE).
  1. Therafter you should join to Business Partner, add an association to I_BusinessPartner, Join on BusinessPartner = ShipToBP. Then expose, organizationBPName1 (maps to the classic Name1 field). Optionally you can also expose, OrganizationBPName2 and BusinessPartnerFullName.
  2. Then join to Business Partner Address
  • Add an association to I_BusinessPartnerAddress.
  • Join on BusinessPartner = ShipToBP and AddressID = ShipToAddressID.
  • Expose:
    • StreetName, CityName, PostalCode, Country, and any other needed address attributes.
  • If no AddressID is stored, you can fall back to the standard address by joining only on BusinessPartner and filtering IsStandardAddress = 'X'.
  1. Here are some analytical considerations to make
  • Mark address and name fields as attributes rather than measures.
  • Keep associations as LEFT OUTER joins so that contracts without a Ship-To partner still appear in analytics.
  • If you need a reporting layer, create a consumption CDS view on top and expose the same attributes.

To summarise, by combining the three released interface views (I_ServiceContractPartner, I_BusinessPartner, and I_BusinessPartnerAddress), you can safely expose Ship-To partner name and address information in your Service Contract analytical cube. This method is fully compatible with Public Cloud extensibility and upgrade safe.

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Monitor/Manage applications in S4 HANA disappear inte...
entry.content:
Hello @KevinV1 

This is usually not random authentication loss; it’s most often caused by Spaces/Pages, catalogue content, and the effects of personalisation or cache.

Quick checks

Is the app listed in App Finder?
If yes, it’s a page/personalisation issue. Reset user personalisation (User → Settings → Reset All Personalisation) or ask an admin to clear it for the user. SAP Support Portal/2661367 - Delete all user-created personalisation, such as groups (including My Home) - Fiori Launchpad      SAP Help Portal/Managing Your Settings

Use FLP Support / App Support tools to see exactly which catalogue or role provides the app and why it’s hidden. (Ctrl+Alt+Shift+P → Launchpad/App Support). SAP Help Portal/Launchpad Support Tools

After upgrades, adopt catalogue changes in Maintain Business Roles (Manage Business Role Changes After Upgrade / Check for Changes). Missing adoptions can cause tiles to disappear until the role is updated. SAP Help Portal-Manage Business Role Changes After Upgrade, SAP Community-Review Business Role Changes before a Major Upgrade in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Browser/cache: test in Chrome Incognito to rule out local cache; empty spaces/pages can be auto hidden if they end up with no visible tiles. SAP Community-SAP Fiori launchpad: Hiding empty spaces and pages

If the app is not in App Finder, re-check the user’s business role,such as catalogue assignments, and adopt any pending changes, then test again.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Assistance Required for Invoking 'CreateFixedAsset' A...
entry.content:
Hi @alihassan_tahqeeq36 

Thank you for sharing the details of your scenario and the screenshots. I understand you are trying to invoke the CreateFixedAsset action from the Fixed Asset Master Data OData v4 API using SAP Cloud Integration but you are facing challenges since the action does not show up in the CPI adapter dropdown.

Here is how you can approach it step by step:

  1. Here is why the action does not appear in CPI

The CPI OData adapter is mainly designed for standard CRUD operations (GET, POST to entity sets, PUT, PATCH).
Bound actions like CreateFixedAsset are not exposed in the dropdown. Instead, they must be called directly via their dedicated endpoint URL.

  1. The Correct Endpoint

The action is invoked with a POST request to a URL like this:

<S4HC_URL>/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_fixedasset/srvd_a2x/sap/fixedasset/0001/FixedAssetSAP__self.CreateFixedAsset

  1. Below is how you can set this up in CPI
  1. In your iFlow, use an HTTP Receiver adapter instead of the OData adapter.
  2. Configure the adapter with:
    •  Method: POST
    • Address: the full action endpoint (see above)
    • Authentication: OAuth2 Client Credentials using the S/4HANA Cloud Communication Arrangement for scenario SAP_COM_0510 (Fixed Asset Integration).
    • Add the required HTTP headers such as Content-Type: application/json and Accept: application/json
  1. For the Payload, you will need to send the request body in JSON, matching the schema of the CreateFixedAsset action.
  2. About SAP__self, you noticed the SAP__self in the action definition, this simply means the action is bound to the entity itself. Technically, you just need to call the action URL directly as described above.
  3. I recommend testing the call first in Postman with the action endpoint, OAuth token, and payload. Once you confirm it works, replicate the same in your CPI iFlow.

I hope this gives you a clear path forward, Benjamin. Please let me know if you would like me to sketch a sample CPI iFlow design so you have a concrete template to start with.

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Cost Component split in Professional Service Scenario J11 / J12 ?
entry.content:

In Margin analysis we now have the requirement to see the rate associated with the activity type posting, split in different cost components. For example, if we charge 10€ for a "password reset", then we want to see this in margin analysis split into 7,50 € employee related costs, 2,00 € Cost Technical Infrastructure and 0,50 € License cost. 

The documentation I found for cost component split in cloud seems only to discuss products which are calculated. Could above requirement be addressed in cloud?

Thanks in advance

Johannes
